title: Secondary – Cycle 2 – Progression of Learning - English Language Arts (2010)
subject: Languages

document.title: Secondary – Cycle 2 – Progression of Learning - English Language Arts (2010)

938B0FFC3959488483B409BC327C5E6A.description: Editorials:Focus on current issues and events in the news,Introduction which situates issue within a local and/or national context,  Stance/role of editor is consistent with the ideology of a given news source and Respect for production constraints that influence the editorial content of a newspaper/magazine/show (e.g. the influence of producer’s political ideology on content; word limit, time restrictions, copyright)

731E25F15F904B5DA301B5A51F3D4151.description: Essays: Introduction which includes a lead, an elaboration of the topic, a clear thesis statement and a path statement, Evidence organized as points in a logical sequence (e.g. using a structure such as classification, cause and effect, compare/contrast,chronology), Conventions to establish a sense of unity and coherence (i.e. paragraphs structured using a formulaic pattern: topic sentence, explanation of the example/idea, evidence to support that example/idea, and reasoning to link back to thesis),Conclusion which wraps up the argument by: generalizing the thesis/ideas to the human condition, elevating specific issues to a universal level, drawing on higher truths, etc. and Proper citation(s) of reference material (e.g. ellipsis points, brackets, formatting, footnotes, bibliography )

2D3C0F93436F4B93AF91519C252BAFEA.description: Debates:Use of a procedure such as Parliamentary procedure,Basic structure: opening statement of the issue and a preview of main arguments, followed by arguments for a point of view with supporting evidence, then arguments against this point of view, time for rebuttal, and concluding with a recommendation in favour of one side ,Rhetorical strategies to address and/or distract opponent such as rephrasing, paraphrasing, and/or redirecting to move debate forward; maintaining eye-contact; using a rational, unwavering tone; and fallacies such as red herring, ad hominem argument, guilt by association/bad company, straw man, Spoken conventions such as intonation patterns, pauses and silences, gestures, turn-taking, use of a moderator and (Reading only) Media conventions for specific effect (e.g. the use of close-up to create a sense of immediacy or involvement in a televised debate)

C8E9C4DA5BF0465C976E3FE37F4A344E.description: Multimodal conventions (e.g. video clips of recent news events in a panel discussion; satirical cartoon with an editorial on same topic)

AFFA4A65B662495EB84F9609ED58FDEB.description: Multigenre conventions (e.g. use of personal narrative in an essay; ‘call to action’ conclusion in an editorial)

2DEED33AFEED4F948DD075D565FC0D46.description: Conventions which establish relationships between ideas and serve to extend the argument (e.g. syntactic structures such as parallel structure and syllogism;transitional words and phrases such as however, subsequently, on the other hand; correlative conjunctions such as if, … then …, rather … than

DB9785A7FE6342B4B4ACFBE9B433D9F2.description: Conventions to establish credibility and authority such as using a formal, academic register; 1st or 3rd person point of view; timeless present tense and passive voice; precise, factual, and/or technical language

5A417B35DFFA4550ACA6837F43D5CC8F.description: Rhetorical strategies to engage and convince reader (e.g. stating basis of argument (pros/cons) upfront, anticipating and addressing opposing viewpoints; using analogies; using historical and/or current events to situate topic; deductive/inductive reasoning, antithesis; and fallacies such as burden of proof, false dilemma/black and white thinking, false cause/non sequitur)

6F5C41065E964613AA272C9C42C939BD.description: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions of Argumentative Texts The student understands the purpose of the following and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading and producing spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts:

FAC5E2C865E8440F9457A17FFBDF703E.description: Essays dealing with issues arising from literature (i.e. literary essay)

55ED1534E2BA454E8A4948653B271BF8.description: Texts dealing with personal and social concerns (e.g. editorial, blog, research thesis)

531DD0ABDC93421DB49EB1F47438385B.description: Essays dealing with issues/topics arising from literature, popular culture and the media

3F2B64BE446D44AD879781F9CB6A00E8.description: Texts dealing with personal and social concerns, such as political blogs, editorials, televised panel discussions, critical essays

75AD1E1CA63C411DB4694859827E8F7A.description: Required Argumentative Texts The student reads and produces the following texts:

4612BFC7D4DF4B2B9BB36173A88F8B18.description: Exposition: Argumentative Texts. Argumentative texts try to convince people of a point of view about a topic or issue through a logical sequencing of ideas and/or propositions.

68D64C59AA4C4A9A8C99FC6223DED1C0.description:
Essays :Thesis/controlling idea (i.e. thesis statement),Introduction with an engaging lead and an elaboration of topic, Evidence organized as points in a logical sequence (i.e. using a structure such as classification, cause and effect, compare/contrast, chronology),Use of a variety of strategies to prove/illustrate point (e.g. anecdote, famous quotations, popular media examples) and Conclusion which convinces reader either to behave (buy, donate, act
– ‘call to action’) or to think a certain way

7155610F706B4DF888D1EC7CFD47F9BB.description: Reviews: Introduction that includes: the title and name of producer of the text being reviewed; an overview of the main topic, genre, critiques and issues raised, Content which includes: background on author and context; comparison with other texts in same genre; critique of producer’s decisions (e.g. particular aspects of the plot, characters, setting, conflicts, theme(s), and/or various literary techniques),Organizational structure that supports the reviewer’s opinion/critique (e.g. compare/contrast, respecting narrative chronology), Conclusion which contains a positive, negative or ambivalent recommendation and Conventions to establish credibility (e.g. informal but expert tone and diction, 1st person point of view)

89FD1E96B08D452DA7FE3E574BCD0847.description: Advertisements (including PSAs): Persuasive techniques such as appeals to basic needs (e.g. ‘fitting in’,‘luxury and style’, ‘doing good’; emotional appeals such as use of testimonials and sad music), Media conventions such as camera language, layout, colour, sound (jingle, repetition, rhyme, voiceover), Manipulation of familiar codes and conventions for specific effect and Transformation of ideas/concept from one mode/medium to another (e.g. creating a spoof PSA based on a current news story)

B5B79BC439DA4186822144B8CEAEDAD6.description: Multimodal conventions (e.g. sound of grasshoppers to indicate deafening silence in a speech; manipulated images in an op-ed piece)

9712C673499B4DBFB2DF8CC5D461897C.description: Multigenre conventions (e.g. use of melodrama in a series of TV ads; use of fairy tale conventions in an opinion column)

EBC5025F68604D4AA6F15DB178A03433.description: Rhetorical strategies such as anticipating and addressing opposing viewpoints, repetition, questions, gestures, intonation patterns, eye-contact and fallacies such as emotional appeals, circular reasoning, begging the question, slippery slope

2BE97007D06D42738F3F57BFF4EE25EE.description: Respect for production constraints that influence the content of a newspaper/magazine/show (e.g. word limit, time restrictions, readership tastes and expectations, layout)

02684B5058684EAE94C9FD5B9BE00B27.description: Persuasive language such as connotation, loaded words, modals (should, would, must), polarizing rhetoric, judging/quantifying/qualifying words

B85C636794F84682AEB7615438692C13.description: Figurative language (e.g. imagery, metaphor, simile, personification)

3BD66C0163A749C4A6B4475551712CEA.description: Figures of speech (e.g. metonymy, euphemism, oxymoron, hyperbole and understatement)

1B17EE68CDF9490684D8BBB792B6A785.description: Humour (e.g. bathos, double-entendre, pun, parody, sarcasm)

FFA87A78CBEE41D08275B94BC792D225.description: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions of Persuasive Texts The student understands the purpose of the following and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading and producing spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts:

AB726A5A62F9432ABC0BDABF53E59C09.description: Essays dealing with personal and social concerns (e.g. opinion column, position paper)

253C5144F9034EFF846E9F1558EAF5C0.description: Advertisements, including public service announcements (PSAs), posters, book trailer

C258744E370F4C569142F7A9C7419980.description: Speeches (e.g. pitch an ad campaign, book talk)

321FF0FF2637495D96DA150CCDAB4EF9.description: Texts dealing with personal and social concerns (i.e. Internet sites, documentary films, speeches)

85E0119B12AC4116B6DDC7A534888167.description: Reviews (e.g. of books, television programs, films, music)

AE7A916A08C849E4ADEE8ABBA609DAB0.description: Advertisements, including public service announcements (PSAs), publicity campaigns, popular slogans, posters, book and film trailers.

1529A81A9E0F448E815E4BD6D3895AB1.description: Required Persuasive Texts The student reads and produces the following texts

52A45CE73AA14DB7AC56083462C8680F.description: Exposition: Persuasive Texts Persuasive texts try to move people to act or behave in a certain way, including selling or promoting a product or ideology

290105E51DAF4463A853F22BD6B4740C.description: Expository Texts Expository texts are constructed in deliberate ways and interpret some aspect of the world in a particular way. Whereas fictional texts may occupy a prominent place in our leisure time, persuasive and argumentative texts are central not only to leisure activities, as in reading newspapers, but also play an important role in postsecondary institutions, different professions and in the world of work in general.

5753C3C70FB34645A0F03D788502953F.description: Interviews:Question and answer (Q & A) structure, including short biographical introduction, open-ended and relevant questions, and follow-up questions: Rhetorical strategies to construct a relationship with the subject such as sharing short anecdotes, contextualizing, eye contact, paraphrasing, showing knowledge of subject.

C82D77DA52E14F01902EE6678A6177AB.description: Research reports : Structure that matches the information reported and expectations of a specific discipline/field of study (e.g. science, social studies):Cause/effect and chronolog and Classification and compare/contras:Visual conventions to convey information, meaning(s) and relationships among ideas such as in a timeline or mind map (e.g. key words and images, colour, lines, arrows, dimension and spacing),Features that elucidate/develop the content: paraphrasing, using examples, description, quotations, definitions Conventions that establish authority and expertise(e.g. formal register, technical/disciplinary diction/word choice, passive voice, proper referencing of sources)

B44832DD56B24EBCAC4E45642B26BEAA.description: News reports :Inverted pyramid structure in short breaking news story (i.e. answering W5 in descending order ofimportance):Features that give a sense of immediacy and prescience in a breaking news report: active voice, simple syntax and diction, eye-witness quotations and photo w/caption: Structure that suits the subject of a feature story (e.g. chronology in a profile/human interest story; cause/effect in an issues-based feature; parallel/convergent structure to interconnect two or more stories with the same theme),Structure that suits the subject of a feature story (e.g. chronology in a profile/human interest story; cause/effect in an issues-based feature; parallel/convergent structure to interconnect two or more stories with the same theme), Features that give a sense of depth and context in a feature news story: background information, flashback, anecdotes, interview data, research information from both sides of the issue, Respect for the production constraints that influence content (e.g. word limit, time restrictions, copyright, ideology):Media conventions for specific effect (e.g. using camera angle and graphics to convey credibility; using on-site correspondent and hand held camera to create a sense of embeddedness)

356E053C1DC4410EB557C179E060E4D8.description: Multimodal conventions (e.g. video clips or still images interspersed throughout a televised interview; sound effects in a radio news report)

E3F7AF270C9248C8A1CC178AADD32ED2.description: Multigenre conventions (e.g. use of case studies in a research report; use of narration and/or description to synthesize interview responses into an in-depth profile or feature article)

4662F21B99FC41AEBF98073EC520D559.description: Conclusion(s) which highlight important facts or findings (e.g. via synthesis, interpretation of data, recommendations

9141E11550FA411B850D342EE86F7FC8.description: Evidence to support details, ideas, concepts (e.g. via a variety of primary sources such as field notes, interviews, artefacts; and, secondary sources such as facts, statistics, contextual information

EE15E48F865A443F8D51030F2A78A766.description: Information selected and synthesized to reflect the bias/stance of writer/producer

5FD11A095DB145758D0E5D14315D32E8.description: Layout which visually cues the reader (e.g. subheadings, call-outs, paragraphs,arrows, headline, by-line, composition of photos/images related to print)

54BBA7F3D93A4309B68154807702D846.description: Information organized and sequenced using a structure such as chronology, classification, compare/contrast, problem/solution, cause/effect

2DB6C68DFB7E4F5CB759DAD47F817D88.description: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions of Reports The student understands the purpose of the following and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading and producing spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts:

BBFD0D4DB4E84FD2B274D928E36F9AFC.description: Research reports: on areas of student interest and/or expertise and on topics of local, national and/or international interest

846A778BB59240B0A973AAAD9AFD1CB8.description: News reports: Short breaking news stories on topics of personal and/or local interest, such as for an online newspaper or blog and Feature news stories on topics of local, national and/or international interest

3CB3532291BF44A28300947E99DB2412.description: Interviews, including written and/or audio and/or video transcriptions

03D5236A7D304A4BA01F04882E27F225.description: Descriptive reports delivered in small groups or to whole class (e.g. plenaries)

FAF77F9D37CE4D8C8114B964CA0A0602.description: Interviews (e.g. in print, on radio and/or television)

1210DE675D59441C98BE1829CA157EF5.description: Research reports on areas of student interest and expertise (e.g. the media, environmental issues, health and well-being)

1D2850E99CDA4225AFCE1DB7E3B8FE9F.description: News reports in different media (e.g. television, radio, Internet, graphic reportage/journalism such as 9/11 Report)

2E94BBD887E24932A80836A80D532847.description: Descriptive reports (e.g. recounts of an event/eye-witness report, preliminary research findings)

7F6B9FAD0D0D45CBA3A0D4F169FCBFFD.description: Required Reports The student reads and produces the following texts:

6B0A1FB73E694DE4A4AF3B2A3A5BEFAA.description: Reports Reports describe the way things are or were, conveying information in a seemingly straightforward and objective fashion. They focus on the classification and/or synthesis of a range of natural, cultural or social phenomena in order to name, document and store it as information.

C5A636DCAD0F4F6F83990BE4E357CA00.description: Multimodal conventions (e.g. use of resources such as blackboard, slideshow, video clips in a spoken explanation)

89B3644E482C4979B6C00ACB22C9B8DB.description: Multigenre conventions (e.g. emotional appeals (persuasive) and testimonials (narrative) in a pamphlet explaining how to recycle)

B984A583DE6048A39E063F1F8B135E5F.description: Rhetorical strategies to engage the intended/target audience and assure their comprehension (e.g. expert to non-expert register, demonstration, checking for understanding, analogy, referents to audience knowledge and experience)

93C09DB38961496EA71855368F179229.description: Visuals to focus reader’s attention on what is most important (e.g. headings, captions, labels, graphics, table of contents)

CF07B4C9EE0B4FC9B3BE8174893108CC.description: Conventions which indicate cause and effect (e.g. clear and precise diction/word choice; causal conjunctions such as because, consequently and therefore; temporal conjunctions such as first, second, when and then; transitional phrases such as for example, in other words, as a result) d.   Visuals to focus reader’s attention on what is most

F1362AF35507483FBCCC64362B81B938.description: Conclusion which reviews the salient points

72DDCE7B380D4440AC2B63DFF319535E.description: Organizational structure to break down, categorize and sequence steps logically (e.g. classification, chronology)

4192D92C6E4D44BCBF7D139C14221F9F.description: Selection and synthesis of steps in a process

567FC8BAD9A848489AD0FA317760C129.description: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions of Explanatory Texts The student understands the purpose of the following and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading and producing spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts:

3B0B59B2A4DC42ACBC17A6F80D29C89D.description: Explanations of a process (e.g. teaching something to peers/class, sharing expertise with others)

BCA93DD0A03143459A6759544CF320A0.description: Explanations of a process (e.g. presentation of a lesson by teacher and/or peers)

798E1E7A03E74E359210D6A6278A8544.description: Required Explanatory Texts The student reads and produces the following texts:

46905D50DE374B32ABA1B5AF4EE63203.description: Explanatory Texts Explanatory texts answer the questions “why” and “how.” Describing a procedure and/or explaining social/natural phenomena, these texts allow people to share their expertise in a range of fields and form the basis of many texts from which we learn throughout our lives, such as textbooks and reference books.

16CE38F82ADC472FBF25F78E6388385B.description: (Reading only) Multimodal conventions (e.g. use of theatrical elements such as costume, set design, makeup, blocking in a stage production; use of cinematic elements such as camera language, colour, lighting and soundtrack in a film)

BAA7A9E129C94052837C85E52258128C.description: Multigenre conventions (e.g. journal entries in a novel; historical footage in a contemporary film)

5F7299C248734545BFCCEFFC81D91D54.description: Conventions of specific text types (e.g. use of gutters and panel shape/size in a comic; use of asides, soliloquy, stage directions in a play; use of stanzaic structure and enjambment in a poem)

CB7EB6BE81C94014A6A310CBF47857DD.description: Conventions of specific literary genres (e.g. use of mythical characters in an allegory; scene gathering all the suspects in a mystery; quest plot structure in a fantasy; plot twist in a tragedy)

D67C052FCA7743D28AB7AD5254175AD5.description: Repetition and/or juxtaposition of symbols or motifs (e.g. allusion)

9B1E56BA07A246329FE7F4AF9658311E.description: Humour (e.g. verbal irony, comic relief, caricature, hyperbole and understatement)

70800D5A305B46A784C9AB425B4F8DEB.description: Point of view (i.e. first person, second person, third person limited and/or omniscient narrator)

6030DE071EF6473882F23030D78B10B4.description: Aesthetic qualities of language (e.g. alliteration, rhyme, rhythm, onomatopoeia)

8773AB49423C444D83A38A2862945D4C.description: Figurative language: metaphor, simile, imagery, personification

CFE4F932916E4BCE8568381AC44D28BA.description: Suspense (e.g. foreshadowing, use of action sequences, spooky music)

69C17A0256D6469DAF3C82468AA18C75.description: Recurring motifs, concepts, and other patterns

F471FC48B5054104915D5FFEF5B7FD8C.description: (Reading only) Structural irony (i.e. a double meaning established by a naive protagonist that continues throughout the text, such as in Treasure Island or Gulliver’s Travels)

8B4FD20844C44A41934D5F4EA55B6A92.description: Features to structure the plot (e.g. series of dramatic monologues in a script; flashbacks throughout a televised crime serial; interchapters in novels such as Grapes of Wrath)

F47862801D3544668A38B55BEFA8AFB4.description: Linear and nonlinear plotting (e.g. flashback, multi-narrative strands, meta-fiction)

8FE5154D849C4991B104B066A9F4DED0.description: Features that move the story forward (i.e. incidents, scenes, episodes, and subplots)

20276318F8364ECEB16C8D3BF62BAFD3.description: Basic plot structure: rising action, climax, denouement and resolution

3A7A936A85C94A5386F090601AB47C12.description: Conflict and resolution of conflict (i.e. central problem around which a story is typically organized) such as man against man, man against nature, issues involving what is right or wrong

8F15055AC222466C880FD41BA727E212.description: Stock and/or flat characters (i.e. characters with only one or two qualities or traits, often stereotypes of individuals and/or groups)

BF40A5FD4E764485BAB623CE038C85FD.description: Major and minor characters (e.g. protagonist, antagonist, anti-hero, foil)

CAC476E382FD4B289BEE2B0ACE937334.description: Setting: the physical landscape and social context in which the action of story occurs (i.e. its time and place, and the descriptive details that construct the world of the story)

C001D3F0DC4D42C28F1CEBDA4FA3E8A0.description: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions of Narrative Texts The student understands the purpose of the following and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading and producing spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts:

9B35903F5B5B4F778C923E1B2DC9E10C.description: Narratives in poetic form (e.g. lyric poetry, free verse, ballad, poetry of social commentary/conscience)

CB071E489D294DD3B1CDDB9420DFB473.description: Narratives in prose form:Derived from personal experiences (own or others’) such as memoir, photo story, historical recount : Fictional narratives such as short story, script for a radio play

AE64DB360AB64DDCA7ACF0DA8B4C5E3C.description: Improvisations (i.e. for problem solving, experimenting with different points of view, specifically Forum Theatre and role-play)

458A46874A5E496984192588C3D0884A.description: Spoken performances (e.g. poetry reading, spoken word, storytelling, dialogues)

5C84911A412842888A2A076FC3C57C22.description: Dramatizations of plays and other narrative texts (e.g. read-alouds, choral reading, scene selections)

97C4BA810A18477B8FCF6CBE2E468045.description: Personal stories (e.g. anecdotes, accounts of family life and autobiographical incidents)

060BCB4627404EB8BA6F2DC3AA81C226.description: Classic, modern and contemporary literature: Written for children and young adolescents and reflecting the variety of texts in the literary tradition, including myths, fairy tales, legends, children’s literature, ballads and other poems and Written for adults and reflecting the variety of texts in the literary tradition, including novels, short stories, plays, poetry, memoir and biography/autobiography

8EE2DCA23A664CE99661557D4FAAF909.description: Popular mass-produced texts such as magazines, graphic novels, films and songs

1AF5E10CC82C4980925C607180E84EBB.description: Young Adult Literature (YAL) in a range of genres including novels, graphic novels, memoirs and poetry

C1D2E9ED817F4661B0AB6B214022539C.description: Required Narrative Texts The student reads and produces the following texts:

AD76D8E626B74BA280CE1505A0CCFC9E.description: Narrative Texts Narrative texts are one of the oldest forms for recording and making sense of human experience, as well as articulating the world of the imagination.

5FF5CC9FADE4499D9C4247FBD26A8EEB.description: Multimodal conventions (e.g. tentative language, gestures in a conference; decoupage/collage and/or personal photos in a journal)

800987F072224ED7B96920D0D7DD91F4.description: Multigenre conventions (e.g. poems in a journal; recount in a self-evaluation conference

C1C86B7C1F214DE5940E13518C4250DE.description: Genre-specific conventions (e.g. use of anecdotes, flashback and humour in a personal essay; questions, sarcasm, examples from other texts in a response; figurative language and doodles in a journal)

0824DDCCB1A24FC9ABFC8160B41B206A.description: Tone and register to suit the genre and engage the intended/target audience, including self (e.g. distant and contemplative about a social issue; personal and sombre about something sad that happened; reminiscent or lamenting about a loss/memory)

7F2F80F964CD4336A0E0CFCA560D1433.description: Rhetorical strategies to build rapport, create a sense of intimacy and closeness, and diminish boundaries between reader and producer (e.g. use of first person (I or we), use of anecdotes, analogies, questions, and metaphors)

49738060D1BB4935907B33BC748AA0C8.description: Conclusion which shares a realization, resolution or judgment

A9909A35C47D4FD0A91FBEE2168BF97E.description: Evidence from own experience including personal, global and/or textual examples

037BF78D067644DB9124C34843882E3A.description: Organizational structure to prioritize, sequence and explore ideas from multiple perspectives (e.g. classification, cause/effect, compare/contrast, chronology)

314F5070AF3A4CC3A989ABCD3B402728.description: Focus on ideas/experiences/qualities that are selected and synthesized

64D9D9D023CF4FD2A93214BEFAB8352E.description: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions of Reflective Texts The student understands the purpose of the following and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading and producing spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts:

911EE9F7ACB7409B9AC5BC9D673A7D1D.description: Texts reflecting on values, experiences, ideas, opinions, state of society today (e.g. responses and interpretations of texts)

3D02708E91C141E39D437E5E5BFC558F.description: Written self-evaluations and reflections, including written feedback to peers

043CD8DA812A4ABABA05A909C0C28329.description: Journals, real or fictional, such as reading logs, media logs, learning/process logs, writer’s notebook, diary

237B34736EAF48519748329B887AB8A4.description: Postproduction discussions (e.g. in small groups, for peer evaluation)

A4B85252B9B34E0D8CE0A00D50C12379.description: Self-evaluation conferences (i.e. presenting contents of the Integrated Profile and peer/teacher feedback)

8D2159E4C2EB4103BD0232C5C2AF5E2D.description: Class and small group discussions, including first readings/initial responses to texts (e.g. group plenaries)

046D36FD4E2F4BB6AC39D91BBE1FEDBA.description: Texts reflecting on values, experiences, ideas, opinions, state of society today (e.g. personal essay, magazine commentary, op-ed piece)

7F505B317FF84522AC4E16C04069647A.description: Self-evaluations and reflections, including peer/teacher feedback conferences

E781F15E24994DEEBBDA652821CC1C07.description: Journals, real or fictional (e.g. multimedia journals, writer’s notebooks and diaries)

83375B49A99E470F9C759B26A9FA4B9F.description: Required Reflective Texts The student reads and produces the following texts:

100B32AE5B164E47A3EACB036729265F.description: Reflective Texts Reflective texts help us to reflect, think and/or wonder about life, current events, personal experiences, as well as to reflect on our actions and evaluate what we learn.

9130CF5655BB4F7E9D9B6F5D02FD8A3C.description: Genre-specific conventions (e.g. quotations from the text in an outline for a literary essay; proposed research resources in an action plan; selection of artefacts to present in a conference)

F453AA2BD91745C389F1D231BCBC3B07.description: Visual conventions to articulate the hierarchy and relationships among ideas/actions (e.g. webbing, arrows, colour coding, layout)

2801118768204D69AC2686065C70753B.description: Conventions associated with thinking something through, such as informal/tentative language, pauses and hesitations, point form, use of capital letters and or other forms of annotation to differentiate ideas

D873BA600F6142CDACB2B92BB051681D.description: Organization, categorization, collation and sequencing of ideas/information

B95C701430E44FDCA6325B751F9B94BC.description: List of actions to undertake or of ideas to discuss/examine (e.g. prioritize tasks, decide on a project’s hypothesis and scope, create a thesis statement)

8116827336E84B70BA4FCEC816D8706A.description: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions of Planning Texts The student understands the purpose of the following and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading and producing spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts:

5AD7A10C7E4A43DEA10964387D4E548A.description: Action plans and proposals for projects (i.e. for action research and independent units of study)

6E55222ED7424940BAFA98C7190FDF0F.description: Outlines and storyboards (i.e. for research, written essays and media productions)

B4A70EB02BA542C5983C570BF974A5D1.description: Self-monitoring texts such as rubrics, checklists, timelines

7EB96F2B02C54D28BA82FD1D72A24025.description: Graphic organizers such as mind maps, clusters, lists

F34DDBE87A2B4067B2C8AE45FEA5702D.description: Notes and informal transcripts based on sources read and/or consulted, including class/instructional notes, and the results of individual and group brainstorming activities (i.e. field notes, minutes)

60FA5590044A40C3910FECBE5F5AAE41.description: Conferences with peers and teacher (e.g. regarding action plan, outline, getting the ‘green light’)

E53749088D5647CE9DAD6282E0ED824E.description: Discussions in media production groups (i.e. to establish roles, make decisions, etc.)

19F3BAFAC2E043E0BF97B31EBE569BA2.description: Models of planning texts (i.e. outlines for research, storyboards, action plans, proposals)

A1BDF3F5D689489B8D32AF1994A6AA87.description: Self-monitoring texts such as rubrics, checklists, project instructions and timelines

43EA844A21A94F29858A47BF59FA6D5D.description: Notes and informal transcripts based on sources read and/or consulted, including class/instructional notes, and the results of individual and group brainstorming activities

2068281E6D414B2EA49B0FE3419877B9.description: Required Planning Texts The student reads and produces the following texts:

398C57FB546640AB925459C2930E4EF9.description: Planning Texts Planning texts are used to plan and organize our thoughts, ideas and actions, and help us to monitor our own learning.

16D2D2933689438E93195429584B7162.description: Required Genres: Structures, Features, Codes and Conventions

1945D8CF9637453792282CD751A29FCD.description: Adopts a stance that promotes the smooth development of a hypothesis, thesis statement or controlling idea in own research

E2573160C0F34BD899B3461ECC0484E0.description: Makes generalizations (e.g. determines statistical significance; chooses relevant evidence to support thesis; summarizes or gives a précis to highlight key points)

B986882DF7B1487CA5AA370803D333BA.description: Categorizes data/information (e.g. collates results of surveys; looks for patterns in data; identifies common themes in interviews)

47D086435A5A483F99AFC7B31824D5D0.description: Own data collection instruments (e.g. interviews, surveys, questionnaires)

90161DE529434255AF6C970F74C07FAD.description: Secondary sources (e.g. reference texts, newspaper articles, books)

1245425487434D0ABAC52C4FC6F68FA7.description: Primary sources (e.g. artefacts, interviews, autobiography, journals/diaries)

F7A04405C480472FA2385C0BBD925355.description: Uses a number of research tools to gather data/information:

15878134EBA04CE7A5317BFE87C6A86E.description: Develops a system to keep track of data/information as s/he researches (e.g. notebook, bibliographic references)

429C850B1F0B47A7AC5FF370E0ECC6A4.description: Selects a research protocol depending on purpose, context and inquiry process chosen (i.e. quantitative or qualitative method)

5F9A9F4FA16C411D8A520D032282E601.description: Narrows topic/subject in order to focus research (e.g. lists pros/cons, creates sub-questions)

1DA3690FE63A499FB48ABBA55D0CFA43.description: Distinguishes between primary and secondary sources, both print and non-print

5161031B9F2C427FAB9CFDB0100097FF.description: Uses ethnography to study a social world relevant to an adolescent

059B71B75681448FA02383C3FAAD8A32.description: Uses action research to effect social change

B47288AF674E41DA98BD5DBA56F618FC.description: Uses problem solving to interpret data and information critically

EF91B59EB79849CAB0255C1436CA118D.description: Reseach Process The student demonstrates control over all required aspects of the research process to produce spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts in a given context or situation.

4B252B7EC03F4057BFB099262A28B798.description: Uses a metalanguage to explain production decisions (e.g. explains the symbolism of the colour red and the mood that patriotic music creates in a book trailer about war)

B91BC52B7E2E40EA8D19277902DDA0B4.description: Uses teacher- peer- and self-evaluation as a resource to consolidate and reinvest new knowledge, understanding and information (e.g. records peer responses in own Integrated Profile for reference in subsequent production tasks)

35F55A93B77B4A28B63CC1919CE3B295.description: Makes effective use of specific feedback throughout all stages of the production process, including rehearsal/dry run

C0CC64E6D8694F5BA22B006F2D330365.description: Transforms the information from one mode or medium to another (e.g. prepares a slideshow that synthesizes the data from an action research project)

70FE7B7516244DEAB7461E7BB013CBB3.description: Manages resources in a presentation (e.g. checks that software is compatible, CDs are cued up)

E9804C55B6E34A758667722652E5C525.description: Uses the appropriate codes and conventions to present the text (e.g. uses a formal register when presenting a poster to the class)

4EBDC6004D804187B50F82E64BC7A081.description: Selects the most effective way to present the text to intended/target audience

D17BD1084D37442CA5F990CF042BF1A0.description: Continuity (e.g. ensures coherent visual style in a comic re: colour, character depiction; checks that formatting is consistent in a written text)

B447219EE8E343B4B1E1A5F7CFB4E652.description: Clarity regarding the layout and presentation of the final draft/version of the text (e.g. arranges the placement of charts, diagrams or images)

20744DE756094AC3AAFDAFA49FEDA90F.description: Surface errors in written language (i.e. spelling and usage conventions, grammar and syntax)

BBE0435EF4CB48F6AD282E31EC6A6C42.description: Use of stylistic conventions for specific effect (e.g. sound effects to create mood; use of exaggerated gory details in a crime scene description)

D9C1F8E7EC174EDEA704BBDD94596820.description: Effectiveness of technology used (e.g. rerecording narration to fill in gaps and/or for audibility in a radio spot; slowing down transitions between images in a digital photo essay so the reader can process them)

420DE2EB49AD4340B03CC7EEDD21777C.description: Accuracy in the use of structure, features, codes and conventions of the text, including respect for media constraints (i.e. applies text grammars correctly)

D990E0E1935D4F90A465F0A316C1029C.description: Coherence in light of the production context, purpose, intended/target audience and production criteria

6914D1D6A7084BD79A6E03F0595D4460.description: Precision in the use of details and/or information

07C8C17472FD419BBA2CDCF230CF5BF6.description: Internal organization of the content (e.g. changes order of images in a photo essay)

BF2507CE94F945258F90EF4E091D13DE.description: Clarity and development of ideas, meaning(s)/message(s)

B3669C21700A484788DF56819103CFAD.description: Evaluates draft/version critically, and makes relevant adjustments to enhance:

4AC4455121894CA7BCFAF23E89FCC98E.description: Respects constraints of the media industry (e.g. length, ideology, copyright, layout)

9B2988AC520C400F8B01F4B9ADF997FC.description: Uses rhetorical strategies and different registers in context (e.g. uses an active voice to project a sense of immediacy)

B86C2D48787E48538A69505FFF3E4E15.description: Uses knowledge about spoken and/or written and/or media modes and genres to make production decisions that enhance the impact of the text on its intended/target audience (e.g. decides to place a dramatic photograph with a feature news story to move the audience)

2EAB7FAB4EA24D7DAE2ABCEC1CD25804.description: Uses structures, features, codes and conventions of a specific text to communicate clearly and enhance meaning(s)/message(s)

7767CA7C27C9487999CD0D7391EA0363.description: Uses relevant technology resources throughout the production process (e.g. uses a still or video camera in a Public Service Announcement (PSA); downloads digital images for a multimedia project)

675B48E3AAD541DBB544DC559675A432.description: Looks into issues of ownership, property and privacy common to the media industry (e.g. checks that copyright and/or legal permission can be obtained; reviews relevant intellectual property laws)

0FBFC990DE0A4471919A0265B1366AC8.description: Manages resources (e.g. makes appointments to administer surveys or conduct an interview; books AV equipment in advance)

2DC47AF1CE334576B3B3A4A2B1D35102.description: Researches to locate material, resources and/or expertise

E5FFAB56627C4186A8791BCC55A07BDA.description: Uses appropriate organizational devices in light of text, purpose, intended/target audience, meaning(s)/message(s) and context (e.g. outline, storyboard)

841EBE45180F44C0A6F1FCD077D264CB.description: Uses a range of stances derived from: Personal experience(s) and knowledge.

17AE67405614475AB6980B5B2B52EEA4.description: Characterizes needs and expectations of intended/target audience to make some decisions regarding content:Familiar audience (e.g. provides additional details or information; sequences events or information to enhance reader’s comprehension) and Distant but known audience, conceptually appropriate for an adolescent (e.g. considers audience knowledge and/or preconceived notions of topic)

C68EBBBFFBFD4AB6A8F7E043C6629892.description: Determines criteria to judge the quality of the text in light of the production context, including purpose and intended/target audience: Familiar audience (e.g. provides additional details or information; sequences events or information to enhance reader’s comprehension) and Distant but known audience, conceptually appropriate for an adolescent (e.g. considers audience knowledge and/or preconceived notions of topic)

2C952BEA016C4FB4910BC96A773F6423.description: Selects a text in light of context, including purpose, meaning(s)/message(s) and intended/target audience

5C49075CF9324EE9823E7AA7A5946025.description: (Media only) Uses collaborative strategies as part of a production team (e.g. adopts different roles, shares expertise, sets and meets deadlines, accepts different points of view, reaches consensus)

D617AD18AADD4574883BEA54BA82B178.description: Aspects of the writer’s/producer’s stance and how these influence readers (e.g. intent, ideology, values, beliefs)

F83ED9A8365441A08F7DE907B43A7314.description: Level of formality of the discourse (i.e. its register)

BE559EE5C7F749AD833916327C16BA1A.description: How the meaning/message is represented and communicated

2E95AA5BD90243E799B0936651FF7CD1.description: How characteristics of the intended/target audience are represented such as their needs, expectations, age group, social status, etc.

C6591744B60D430B8A4CD59A76F4AA47.description: Purpose and context in which the text was produced that influence features such as its style, rhetorical devices, textual conventions and content (e.g. an advertisement for sports equipment in a popular sports magazine; an airline safety pamphlet; a film review on a newspaper Web site)

41CEAE735F85486F91B815CF25C6F74A.description: Unique structure(s), features, codes and conventions of a specific text type. See also the Required Genres section of this document for specific structures, features, codes and conventions.

406460BD21A64C66A4441EB4C9A38A96.description: Examines model texts to guide production decisions, specifically:

0ADA6F18E6DF426DA83BB68C6EE6A7C7.description: Production Process The student applies the stages of the production process to produce spoken, written, media, multigenre and multimodal texts in a given context or situation.

7D13D8ED6B0140119B2F688B56872CBB.description: Uses vocabulary and terminology that apply to a specific topic and/or genre (e.g. scientific terms in a feature article; literary terms proper to an Elizabethan sonnet)

8D30E9B9A1F8470693026037469E8137.description: Draws coherent conclusions by making inferences and generalizations

4DFD2B4FF4704099974FBC847A327DD8.description: Analyzes how readers are positioned or situated by the text and how this can alter an interpretation (e.g. considers how “generation gap” stereotypes might affect different readers)

881946D74A8045E58A8B5BFF434A228A.description: Compares/contrasts own ideas, values and beliefs with those presented by writer/producer (e.g. notions of beauty promoted in a teen magazine; portrayal of the American South in novels written between 1920 and 1945)

9A43483DEEC2406C86A6BAC5BD0C8E32.description: Establishes interrelationships between the structure and features of the genre, the context in which the text is produced, and the impact of the text on self as reader (e.g. the use of dramatic irony in Romeo and Juliet allows Shakespeare to heighten the tragedy of their suicides, while reminding today’s reader that in the 16th century, star-crossed lovers had very few choices as to how their situation might be resolved)

87BF14912F684A4CA729C59FF7B44779.description: Analyzes how the text attempts to attract and hold the reader’s attention (e.g. how continuity is established in an argument; how humour, sound or music is employed to special effect in film; how structural irony or vivid details are used to create suspense in a narrative)

9A27ABEC63C04DBAAE0E5FE5E7FCD6D8.description: Explains how fact and opinion are represented by the writer/producer and to what effect

8333C52352E344C1827BD6F1BA6F027B.description: Explains how real and imaginary are represented by the writer/producer and to what effec

FD3879EEB7744420959CC725A6762D29.description: Analyzes dominant features of the text, such as its point of view, use of persuasive language, connotation and denotation, etc.

99AAC259123348379FB6981D6B6557A2.description: Compares/contrasts with other texts that treat the same issue/topic/theme /event

8A1E49CF234C455F82BA876573884026.description: Cites evidence from the text to substantiate own ideas, statements, questions and opinions

8BA28456F54E489E9F909EB04E13AD55.description: Selects relevant evidence to illustrate and justify own interpretation:

6287B75FDEFB4921987747E5658B5181.description: Selects a mode and genre that conveys own interpretation to advantage in light of situation/context (e.g. interprets the conflict faced by a central character through a journal that includes illustrations and print)

E89A72B43D5D42319EDB7C263745648F.description: Organizes elements of own interpretation in order to achieve coherence and communicate clearly

6C62AEA55FA04590900C60B4D0AEE28B.description: Determines own working hypothesis, theory, controlling idea, or thesis statement

83CBEFCCB30B4B74B8048561C495EA40.description: Interrelates aspects of his/her reading profile, the structure, features and content of the text, and its social/cultural/historical context

9629554518714CA6B79E76A62D40A58F.description: Identifies dominant discourses and how they shape the writer’s/producer’s intended meanings/messages (i.e. recognizes whose voices are heard and whose voices are ignored or marginalized in a given text)

82DFF2807C3947E09FECFE6D22784A19.description: Analyzes implications and/or impact and/or influence of stereotyping or cliché, false representation, gender bias and/or power relations within a text on the meaning(s)/message(s) communicated

BCB53EADC28A4D86A5DA37842F3F739E.description: Connects significant facts/information in relation to main idea(s), hypothesis, thesis statement or stance conveyed by writer/producer (i.e. means through which writer/producer interprets information or uses argument or persuasion to move the reader)

30DC24A3D59844A9A6BA26B251BE3C01.description: Identifies characteristics of writer/producer and how this influences the purpose of the text, its meaning(s)/message(s) and other aspects of the context in which it is produced and read (e.g. inherent values and how these are represented; influence of a social/cultural/historical context on their sensibility and/or central argument)

8201B5665F9C437FB2C4717F0EEF239D.description: Locates evidence in the text of how the writer/producer creates a relationship between the text and its reader (e.g. identifies aspects that appeal more to women than to men in a magazine ad)

71ACEB234991476F8E59142CD01ACAA4.description: Draws generalizations and conclusions based on evidence in the text (e.g. synthesizes key ideas and information)

DEB84E2199C742BE8158DF060BD82359.description: Draws inferences about the view of the world presented in the text despite its apparent objectivity (e.g. in a research report that presents only one side of the greenhouse effect)

2EB7E2EB7634465A8DCC0FA48C67E858.description: Demonstrates understanding of how information is interpreted and communicated in different information-based (spoken, written, media) genres:

399BA7118F7A4F95AA9C22FD62BE270B.description: Known characteristics of an open narrative text (e.g. figurative language in a short story or symbolism in a poem)

62C43E3513BB43B2A7598133C6B6A5D9.description: Known characteristics of a closed narrative text (e.g. the formulaic pattern in a heroic myth or in a serialized spy thriller such as James Bond)

B23C1B32B5EB46DD9DF8BCDAC5AF6D0C.description: Demonstrates understanding of the difference between familiar open and closed written narrative texts by identifying:

33F03A52938849ABA35529F9A374E550.description: Keeps track of changes in own first reading/initial response as s/he works toward a more considered interpretation of the text (e.g. makes notes, highlights significant sections of text, begins a tentative outline)

FEB8AC516B65476C9126FA8FF2F162C9.description: Extends/supports/scaffolds first reading/initial response by examining details in the text (e.g. draws on own reading profile; uses information gained through rereading, immersion into texts and exchanges with other readers and teacher)

31C7FCDB4CB54D1683E049AC272A444E.description: Produces a coherent first reading/initial response to a text. See below for what constitutes a first reading/initial response to a text.

93BC2146E617415AAAD3BDA1A0DD486C.description: Draws on needed background knowledge and experiences related to the social and/or cultural and/or historical context in which the text was produced in order to read critically (e.g. consults other texts written at the same time)

7343D85F21A548CDB6D64EF715E4B8D5.description: Uses cues conveyed by the structure, features, codes and conventions of spoken, written and media genres to determine significance in a text while listening/reading/viewing (e.g. recognizes the conventions of television news that are associated with credibility; recognizes the structural devices used in an editorial that strengthen an argument)

EA3ABDBA189B4B34804A40A6CD7BA6DF.description: Adjusts reading stance(s) and strategies to determine possible meaning(s) or message(s) in spoken, written, media, multimodal and multigenre texts

5A463DAE53B24E9EB83A934FF49ACB7B.description: Considers the social function(s) of the text and the context in which it was produced, as well as his/her own reading context, to determine appropriate reading stance

D86FDE8C691B48B98DAA199DBE154D2D.description: Reading Process: Interpreting Texts The student applies the stages of the reading process to interpret a spoken, written, media, multimodal and/or multigenre text.
